b-hadron spectroscopy study based on the similarity of double bottom baryon and bottom meson

The dynamical similarity which exists between the λ-mode excited bbq baryons (q refers to the u, d, and s quarks) and the b̄q mesons inspires us to carry out a combined study of their spectroscopy. In this work, the masses and strong decays of these low-lying bq̄ and bbq states are studied by the same theoretical methods, and the dynamical similarity which is implied in their mass spectra and strong decays are also discussed. The recent discovered b̄q states, including the BJð5840Þ, BJð5970Þ, BsJð6064Þ, and BsJð6114Þ, are analyzed. According to our result, the BJð5840Þ could be assigned as a 2S state, while the BJð5970Þ could be regarded as a member of the 1Dð2−; 3−Þjq¼5=2 doublet. The BsJð6064Þ and BsJð6114Þ are probably the D-wave states. Especially, they could be explained as the members of the 1Dð1−; 2−Þjq¼3=2 and 1Dð2−; 3−Þjq¼5=2 doublets, respectively. The predicted masses and decay properties of other unknown b̄q=bbq states may provide useful clues to the future experiment.
DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevD.105.074014
I. INTRODUCTION
The study of hadron spectroscopy is a useful approach to deepen our understanding of the nonperturbative behavior of strong interaction. In the past decade, big progress has been made on the observation of bottom baryons, which is a crucial step to construct a complete b-hadron spectroscopy. Among these observations, the Λbð5912Þ, Λbð5920Þ, Λbð6072Þ, Λbð6146Þ, Λbð6152Þ, Ξbð6100Þ, Ξbð6327Þ, and Ξbð6333Þ which were reported in Refs. [1–6] have a close relation to the low-lying Λb and Ξb baryons. Meanwhile, these P-wave Σb, Ξ0b, and Ωb states were also established one by one which are mainly due to the effort from LHCb [7–10]. In contrast to the situation of single bottom
baryons, none of the double bottom baryons has been discovered, which is becoming not only a challenge but also an opportunity for the future experiments. If further checking the status of bottom and bottom-strange mesons, we can find that the families of bottom and bottom-strange mesons are far from being established since there are only seven states collected in each of the bottom and bottomstrange meson families, which can be referred to the Particle Data Group (PDG) [11]. Thus, constructing the spectroscopy of bottom and bottom-strange mesons is still on the way. Before introducing the motivation of the present work, we
should mention the lesson from the investigation of single heavy baryons. Lanzhou group has systematically studied the single heavy baryons by the nonrelativistic constituent quark models [12–17], where the diquark picture was employed. These studies not only depicted the newly observed single heavy baryons, but also have stood the test of later experimental observations. For examples, the predicted properties ofP-waveΩb [16] andD-waveΞb [17] stateswere confirmed by the LHCb experiments [6,10]. To some extent, our works could be regarded as a typical example of applying the diquark picture to hadron spectroscopy. For the double bottom baryon, we may also treat this
interesting system as a quasi-two-body problem if putting

Indeed, the heavy-diquark-light-quark picture has been taken into account when calculating the mass spectrum of double bottom baryons [18–20]. In the following, we should mention the similarity between the double bottom baryon and the bottom meson if the diquark picture is considered. As illustrated in Fig. 1. the double bottom baryon system could be simplified as a quasi-two-body system in the diquark picture, where the heavy diquark has the same color structure as a heavy antiquark in the bottom meson. Thus, it is naturally expect that the λ-mode excited bbq baryons have the similar dynamics to the bottom mesons. So it provides a possibility to carry a combined study of the mass spectrum of these two kinds of b-hadrons. Besides giving their mass spectrum, in this work, we also
focus on the strong decay properties of the bottom meson and double bottom baryon together. As shown later, most of the low-excited λ-mode bbq states are expected to be below the ΛbB and ΞbB thresholds. Thus, for the strong decays of these double bottom baryon excitations, two bottom quarks which transit into a final bbq state could be treated as a whole (see Fig. 2). So the heavy diquark is just a spectator in the decay process, which is similar to the strong decay of an excited b̄q meson. Therefore, the similarity should exist not only in the spectroscopy of low-lying b̄q and bbq states, but also in their strong decays. It means that these two kinds of b-hadrons can be investigated in the same
theoretical scheme for their masses and strong decays. In this way, the model parameters fitted by the known b̄q mesons can provide a valuable reference to the bbq system since none of bbq states has been discovered. The proposed approach is different from most of studies in the literature, where the b̄q and bbq states were studied individually. The paper is organized as follows. After the introduction,
the theoretical scheme is introduced in details in Sec. II. The mass spectra and strong decay behaviors of these lowlying b̄q and bbq states are investigated in Sec. III and IV, respectively. The similarities of the b̄q and bbq systems which are implied in the predicted masses and strong decays are further discussed in Sec. V. Finally, the paper ends with the conclusion and outlook in Sec. VI.

sections.heading: II. THEORETICAL SCHEME
sections.text:
It has been a long time since Savage and Wise proposed the superflavor symmetry which can be related to the discussion of the properties of the Q̄q mesons and QQq baryons [21]. The emergence of superflavor symmetry is a consequence of the heavy quark limit. In the limit of mQ → ∞, two heavy quarks in the QQq baryonic system may form a small weakly bound color triplet subsystem. In literature [22], the fQQg subsystem is also referred to be the heavy diquark. As an approximation, this heavy diquark could be regarded as a static source of color, which plays essentially the same role as the heavy antiquark in a heavylight meson. The superflavor symmetry has been developed and
applied by Cohen [23], Roberts [24,25], Ma [26] and their collaborators. An important application of the superflavor symmetry is to obtain the properties of these unknown double heavy baryons from the well-measured heavy-light mesons. The superflavor symmetry was used in Ref. [23] to predict the mass difference of two ground double heavy baryons with JP ¼ 1=2þ and JP ¼ 3=2þ, respectively, where the masses of two ground heavy-light mesons (the pseudoscalar and vector mesons) were taken as the input. Based on the superflavor symmetry, the selection rule and the spin-counting relation for the strong decays of the double heavy baryon were studied in Ref. [25]. The superflavor symmetry was incorporated into an effective Lagrangian approach in Ref. [26]. Then the masses and decays of ground and 1P (with JP ¼ 1=2− and JP ¼ 3=2−) doubly heavy baryons were predicted. Recently, the superflavor symmetry was also extended to investigate the tetraquark system QiQjq̄kq̄l [27]. In this work, we are also dedicated to the application of

sections.heading: A. The B meson
sections.text:
As shown in Table II, the low-lying B mesons are far from being well established. At present, only the Bð5280Þ, B ð5325Þ, B1ð5721Þ, B 2ð5747Þ, B Jð5732Þ, BJð5840Þ, and BJð5970Þ are collected by the PDG [11]. Among them, the Bð5280Þ, B ð5325Þ, B1ð5721Þ, and B 2ð5747Þ were established in experiment without controversy. However, two broad 1P bottom mesons are not established. As a disputed candidate of the 1P Bmeson, the B Jð5732Þwas reported in Refs. [39–42], where the measured resonant parameters from different experiments are listed in Table III. Exploring higher excited B mesons was continuing. The
L3 Collaboration reported a bottom meson which could be a 2S or 1D candidate in the hadronic decay process of the Z boson [42]. Its mass and decay width were measured to be 5937 21 4 MeV and 50 22 5 MeV, respectively. However, this B state has never been confirmed by other experiments and none of other the higher excited B state was found in the next many years. In 2013, the CDF Collaboration found a state Bð5970Þ in the Bπ final states [44]. Two years later, the LHCb Collaboration reported two B resonances, the BJð5840Þ and BJð5960Þ [45]. So far, the spin-parity quantum numbers of these reported B mesons are still undetermined (see the discussions in Ref. [46]). In this work, we try to identify their properties by combing our theoretical result with the experimental data.

sections.heading: 1. The 1P states
sections.text:
The 1P bottom mesons B1ð5721Þ and B 2ð5747Þ have been established by experiments [11]. As shown in Table IV, the masses of the B1ð5721Þ and B 2ð5747Þ can be well reproduced in our calculation, where we assign these two states as the 1P1 and 13P2 states of the B meson.
Thus, the reported B1ð5721Þ and B 2ð5747Þ belong to the 1Pð1þ; 2þÞjq¼3=2 doublet, which indicates that the B1ð5721Þ and B 2ð5747Þ should have similar decay behavior. By the EHQ formula, the total decay width of the Bð13P2Þ meson is calculated to be 26.7 MeV, which is consistent with the experimental data [45]. Under this assignment, the partial width ratio of the Bπ and B π decay mode is obtained to be
RðB 2ð5747Þ0Þ ¼ BðB 2ð5747Þ0 → B πÞ BðB 2ð5747Þ0 → BπÞ ¼ 0.89; ð7Þ
which is also comparable with the LHCb result for the B 2ð5747Þ state, i.e., RðB 2ð5747Þ0Þ ¼ 0.71 0.14 0.30 [45]. Thus, the study of the decay behavior of the B 2ð5747Þ enforces the conclusion of the B 2ð5747Þ as a Bð13P2Þ meson. This novel phenomenon may reflect that the superflavor symmetry is an effective symmetry for these different kinds of bottom hadron systems. In the following, we should mention the spin-orbit

The spin-orbit inversion of these P-wave heavy-light mesons has been discussed in Refs. [81–83] for many years. Since the P-wave bottom mesons are not established, the spinorbit inversion of the P-wave heavy-light mesons remains inconclusive. According to our predictions in Table IV and XI, the spin-orbit inversion should appear in theD-wave b̄q and bbq states since the members in the jq ¼ 5=2multiplet are about 70–100 MeV lower than the jq ¼ 3=2 multiplet (see Fig. 4). We try to give a qualitative explanation to this

For the D-wave excited b̄q=bbq states, the contribution from the spin-dependent interactions arising from the short-range one-gluon exchange contribution becomes smaller, while the contribution from the Thomas-precession term from the long-range confining potential becomes dominant. Thus, the first term in Eq. (4), as the mainly spin-dependent interaction for the orbitally excited b̄q=bbq states, could be a negative number. In fact, the results from Refs. hadron systems can be found in their strong decay behaviors. For the L-wave (L ¼ 1, 2) excited b̄q and bbq states, the members in the jq ¼ Lþ 12 multiplet seem to be much narrower than those in the jq ¼ L − 12 multiplet. This phenomenon can be reflected from our results in Tables V, VII, X, XIII, XIV, and XV, where the predicted decay widths of these states in the jq ¼ Lþ 12 multiplet are at least one order smaller than those of the states in the jq ¼ L − 12 multiplet. sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION AND OUTLOOK
sections.text:
The dynamical similarities between the b̄q and bbq systems provide us a possibility to carry a combined study of their properties in the same theoretical framework. In this work, we systematically investigate the mass spectra and strong decays of these low-lying B, Bs, Ξbb, andΩbb states. Our result not only decodes these newly observed states BJð5840Þ, BJð5970Þ, BsJð6064Þ, and BsJð6114Þ, but also reveals the similarities of the b̄q and bbq systems existing in their mass spectra and strong decays. According to our results, theBJð5840Þ could be a 2S state with JP ¼ 0− or JP ¼ 1−, while the BJð5970Þ could be a candidate of the 1Dð2−; 3−Þjq¼5=2 doublet. Since a lowenergy photon from the B → Bγ decay was not reconstructed in the realistic measurements of the CDF [44] and LHCb [45] collaborations, the BJð5840Þ signal can be resulted by two 2S states of the Bmeson. Similar phenomenon may also happen for the BJð5970Þ signal which could contain two states of the 1Dð2−; 3−Þjq¼5=2 doublet. Thus, we suggest the experiment to further identify the spin-parity quantum numbers for these states, or measure the ratio ΓðB πÞ=ΓðBπÞ, which is helpful to clarify the nature of BJð5840Þ and BJð5970Þ.
